abstract.p: Noel D Sturtz letter disputes September 15 Science Times article on lead exposure to infants through breast milk (S)

block.p: A Sept. 15 Science Times item on lead exposure in infants through breast milk says ''high lead levels in the blood of infants and children can result in brain damage, behavioral problems and liver and kidney disorders.'' In fact, relatively low doses are linked to deleterious effects.

A Sept. 15 Science Times item on lead exposure in infants through breast milk says ''high lead levels in the blood of infants and children can result in brain damage, behavioral problems and liver and kidney disorders.'' In fact, relatively low doses are linked to deleterious effects.

As early as 1943 psychological deficits were attributed to lead doses otherwise insufficient to cause clinical encephalopathy. These studies were confirmed by Dr. Herbert L. Needleman in the 1970's, who correlated childhood lead exposure to school performance, reading ability, attention span, classroom behavior and lower mean verbal I.Q. scores.

Other investigators have pointed to umbilical-cord blood lead levels as a portent for diminished intelligence. Owing to these impairments and a developing nervous system, many experts argue that there is not yet any blood lead level safe for infants and children. NOEL D. STURTZ Aventura, Fla., Sept. 16, 1998
